text:
I would start with a comprehensive mapping of your existing content inventory and the range of intents/perspectives that are ranking for them. Tools I would use during this step are Google Search Console and Google search (advanced operators).

Next, use a tool like Ahrefs to do competitive analysis to make sure I'm not glossing over any topics/intents that I didn't know. Along with mining information from sales calls, support requests, and talking internally to other team members (shoutout <@UJG9WTEKG>'s Superpath Pro course on "how to generate infinite topic ideas").

Finally, prioritize all the topics based on business goals (eg. bottom of the funnel, "request a quote page", etc) in a Google Sheets / Airtable. And then Clearscope when the actual writing/refreshing of content begins.

elements.text:

text: <@UJG9WTEKG> Demandwell is LEGENDARY. They're a hybrid software + consulting SEO/organic traffic firm. The consulting side of things is :fire:, and their product takes away the hassle of keyword research, combing through contracted pillar pages + blog posts to make sure keywords/phrases and linking are both correctly done. Demandwell is a start-up, so there's tons of room to grow and the product isn't fully refined, but it's already saving my teammates and I time so we spend less time researching/writing and more time editing/publishing valuable SEO content.

text: that's exactly how I am thinking about it! "What's my job." I _just_ <https://twitter.com/BenyaminElias/status/1382732288182652934|hit publish on a tweet> about how SEOs think about their jobs wrong.

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/BenyaminElias|@BenyaminElias>: SEO as a field is misnamed.

So many SEOs fall into the optimization trap. Trying to reach a 100% optimal site with no errors.

But the job isn't optimization. It's growth — traffic and biz from search.

You can be 100% "optimal" and not grow, and 50% optimal with hypergrowth.

text:
I think it can be hard to have clear objectives within content and SEO, because what you produce doesn't always directly tie into revenue. I try to work around that by looking at the pipeline we drive from marketing leads and work my way backwards. If we need X pipeline, we need X sales accepted leads, X SQLs, X MQLs and X visitors. That way I can tie content to a revenue number. For branding goals I look at branded search volume growth and direct traffic (although with the slow death of cookies, this is a much muddier indicator than it was a couple of years back).

Does this always work? Nope, but it's better than just trying to increase views or rankings.

text: Folks, question! I'm working on the content strategy for ERIKS and I've been asked if we can use *content to drive audience insights.* Obviously we can source new leads through content, but what they want is to know more about our target audience needs, customer journey, etc, etc through how they interact with content. Has anyone ever done such an exercise and if so, how to best go about it?

text: Hi all I wanted to see how everyone goes about measuring there content impact.  We are a b2b industrial product ecommerce company.  In Google analytics most of our sales are attributed to our paid google ads efforts.  We do receive some direct traffic sales and some from organic.  But wondering what solutions everyone uses to see if full on content marketing is producing results, for reference about 1/2 of our site visits (50k per month) come to our blog.

text:
Certainly can, but the kinds of insights you can glean up front while developing a strategy may be different from the insights you can learn after you've been publishing content for some time.

Initially, keyword search volumes can tell you some things about which problems people experience most frequently. They could also give you some insight into which products people most commonly compare when they're further down the funnel and in the consideration phase.

As you publish content though, keep a close eye on how it performs in terms of rankings, traffic, and conversions. Make it a weekly or at least monthly task to really sit down and manually analyze what aspects about that content could be affecting performance positively or negatively.

Over time you might be able to learn that certain topics or formats resonate that can give you insight into how your customers and what they want from you based on patterns in how content performs. For example, you might notice your audience is looking for examples of how others have solved a problem, so you might include more examples in your content. Then you might notice certain pieces with certain types of examples centered around certain problems might consistently be performing well, and that might tie into something your customer success or support teams can tell you more about based on their conversations with customers.

text: I’m currently working on a single source of truth internal linking situation — the idea is that certain phrases will always link to the same resource/pillar page/guide. Ex: “retirement planning” or “planning for retirement” would always be linked to our guide to retirement planning.

elements.text: I’m currently working on a single source of truth internal linking situation — the idea is that certain phrases will always link to the same resource/pillar page/guide. Ex: “retirement planning” or “planning for retirement” would always be linked to our guide to retirement planning.

text: I'm not sure if this is helpful during the planning phases, but the TL;DR answer I'd offer is: yes, but it's going to be a process rather than a one-off exercise. It might be best to have a method for analyzing content to find those insights rather than trying to provide those insights before you've published something. It might also be helpful to know which specific questions stakeholders have so you can try to plan your content strategy around creating content that would help answer them for you.

text:
I'm working on some extremely extensive pieces of content with a client and have realized over the course of researching, writing and setting up promo, I probably spend 20+ hours on each one.

They can range from 4000 to 7000+ words and require a lot of scientific research and references.

Just curious as to how you all would price something like this? I know I need to increase my rate and have a talk with the client, since we didn't thoroughly understand the extent of the work that would be required when we started this project but both want to see it through to the end.

elements.text:
I'm working on some extremely extensive pieces of content with a client and have realized over the course of researching, writing and setting up promo, I probably spend 20+ hours on each one.

They can range from 4000 to 7000+ words and require a lot of scientific research and references.

Just curious as to how you all would price something like this? I know I need to increase my rate and have a talk with the client, since we didn't thoroughly understand the extent of the work that would be required when we started this project but both want to see it through to the end.

text:
Hey <@U01HEQWRG0G>! I'd start by listing all the deliverables and itemized work you're performing. Note how long each takes. Multiply by your hourly rate (even if that's not how you price projects publicly). Now you have a baseline of what the project is worth in terms of your time.

Next, is that number something your client would feel comfortable paying for this project?

For example, if your # ends up being$10k but that's wildly out of line for X # pieces of content, you'll know to revisit your fee.

Overall, I'd recommend selling the value and not the individual deliverables.

Hope I'm being clear with this. Feel free to ask any questions! Hope that helps.
